posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Whats the difference between using linseed oil vs paint thinner for thinning oil paints?
Everything I can find online seems to talk about them interchangeably, is there a reason to use one over the other?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6390809
+linseed oil makes the paint have more oil (oil to pigment ratio increases) slower drying, more gloss, not as easy to paint over dry, harder for atmospheric vapors and moisture to penetrate, more yellowing, more flexible, used for glazes
+paint thinner makes makes the oil thinner (oil to pigment ratio remains the same but effectively lower since it also breaks down oil) leaner and thinner paint layer, more matte surface, pigment can be unbound if thinned too much, more susceptible to dirt and moisture penetration due to microscopic pores, faster drying, mostly used for under layers

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6399981
Brushes and brush pens can be a bit difficult to get used to since you feel much less contact with the surface, but they're a lot of fun. Definitely the most versatile mark-making wise, but it takes a bit of practice to be able to do very fine detail work with them.
Pic related is great since you can control how much ink is loaded on it for drybrush effects and stuff, unlike the Pentel Pocket Brush which is always wet (which makes it a bit more difficult to handle, too).
Dip pens aren't bad choices either, but they also take some getting used to. Just wanted to mention brushes since I feel like they're a bit overlooked these days which is a shame.
Waterproof ink gives brushes a shorter lifespan, but it's not that big of a deal. Pen nibs break and brushes eventually lose their point, but you'll still probably go through them much slower than fineliners.

>>6404987
to clarify
i wasn't talking about watercolor. i meant that even for drawings in dry media i only use pure cotton paper, (but not watercolor cotton paper.) if you explain to buyers of watercolor that something is made of cotton, that's simply expected, especially if the buyer has been in the market for buying watercolor works.
i go beyond what is expected when it comes to materials. for oil painting, the standard is simply to use tube paints, with titanium as the white, over acrylic gesso. i grind from dry pigments, use the best lead white available, and use lead oil ground with the same lead white.
it's not merely an issue of the work fading or deteriorating in 10 years or in their lifetime either. as there are practices and materials that i admit are more archival, but are simply not as beautiful, prestigious, or expensive. aluminum panels, mdf, and plywood are very stable, but are not as inspiring as a joined solid wood panel with hand cut butterfly keys. when it comes to works of art, i consider the support as part of the art, so they must be beautiful as well.
or some materials might outlast others in a few hundred years, but the more available materials are good enough.

posts.com:
>>6415758
there are illustrations of both in use or separately.
palette is good for mixing various tones and making the range of movement more efficient in painting. it also means the paint is somewhat more paste-like. mixtures from the paste can be thinned down with water or more medium, or painted dry thinly. i notice that palettes were generally smaller, because the mixes were simpler and they painted differently colored parts separately, and that the familiar kidney shaped palette became more common later.
shells and bowls are good for fluid paints. the ribs of the shells or the rim of the bowl makes it easy to remove excess moisture from the brush. the bowl shape also means that moisture evaporates slower. one can make different mixes in separate shells but this can be wasteful since you often only need a small amount of each especially since tempera is painted very thinly.

>>6402392
comparing your art to the one you have sent i have a few things i would point out.

It looks like you have a grasp on "hue shifting", but there's also something else to consider when it comes to color and that is value. How light or dark something is on your screen.
there are two ways to check your value:
1. if you are on windows, you can assign color modes to your screen. One of them is monochrome. I have this set to a hot key (something like c+shift+windows?) do i can switch back and forth with ease.
2. fill a layer above your whole work with white. set it to "saturation". turn it on when you want to see your values.

If you want your art to have the vibe of the art that you sent, try matching the skin values to that one. You'll see that there is a large range from white to black

Second, try a smaller brush size. Your lines are much thicker than the art that you have sent.

my only other advice to give is.. hwve you studied color theory yet? It comes naturally to some people, but if it hasn't for you, I'd try one of those tumblr era color pallete challenges where you only use the 5-6 colors in a pallete that you like. Over time, it will come naturally. I still copy colors from existing pieces, because some times it helps when i have no clue what to do for the colors.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6403190
>>6403270
Just steal the colors of whatever it is you are studying with the picker tool. Anime tends to be very saturated so until you get a feel for recognizing how to pick the colors yourself in your program of choice without cheating, you can do that. Personally I tend to underestimate how saturated something is when I pick colors. Another thing that might throw you off is working on a white background. I usually do lineart and coloring on top of a very light cool gray (contrasts with skin well and is easier on eyes, and even traditional paper is never pure white due to lighting), and you can leave it that way until you're done assuming it's just a figure floating in a void.

>>6420701
Building visual library over time. The ability to recall things you’ve previously drawn or seen and being able to confidently build a form from what you recall. Not physically trying to picture the subject in your head like the apple demonstration, but physical attributes you can remember how to draw from last time you did it. It’s >justdraw but not at the same time. Don’t just draw mindlessly by copying contours and symbols but just be more mindful when you do studies/draw. Plus just doing more, that’s where >justdraw comes in handy, but it’s not as simple as just putting a line to paper cuz retards do that for years and expect results without putting thought into it. Also pyw

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Some ways to bridge the gap:
-look at a ref, take it away, draw what you remember, check it against the ref, correct
-pick a pose or scene ref, then draw some OC or existing character in the pose, or draw the scene in some different style
-pick a scene ref, sketch the scene, then add some new detail or object from imagination
-draw a figure from reference, then draw a figure from imagination beside it i\on the same plane
-doodle as many of the simplest, most gestural figures you can manage, in whatever poses come to mind - if they fall apart halfway through and turn into aimless scribble, whatever, do another one
-either buy a well-articulated artist's mannequin or digital 3D posing model, and manipulate it as much as possible, trying to get to where you have some approximation of a posable model in your mind

Also, as dumb as it sounds, be confident. Just come up with what you want to draw, and start drawing as best as you can.

posts.name: Why isn't art fun anymore?
posts.com:
I can draw. I can paint. I can sculpt. I can do art on the level I always wanted to, create literally anything I want. I'm far more flexible than even some of the artists I look up to.

But fuck I hate art now. It's not like it's hard, hell anyone who says this shit is hard clearly just isn't using references. I just don't get it.

It used to be fun to talk to other artists. I used to like designing characters and dreaming up stories for them. I used to genuinely admire other people's art. Now I can't fucking stand artists because they're all whiney self-important cunts and I only ever look at others' art with either harsh judgement or jealousy.

Where did the fun go in this shit? Did art change or did I?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
This thread is dedicated to master studies, where you copy artwork you admire as a form of study. They are the quickest way to improve and learn about any fundamental you are having problems with. If you need to work on your hands, copy hands from other artists, and if you're having trouble with rendering, make careful studies of paintings with lighting you admire. Studies can be quick or long. You can even copy anatomy books like Bridgman, Morpho, and Hogarth. The type of studies you want to do depend on your personal goals and the types of problems you are grappling with.

Artists of all levels are welcome. Critiques and redlines are encouraged.

Recommended watching:

You mean David Finch? The extra girth makes it easier to hold in general. You can hold it with a more relaxed grip or since it is soft, grip it tight without much strain on your hand. This helps to ease cramping from long sessions. It also makes it a bit easier to control of the tip of the pencil.

Make a study
Put away the reference / previous drawing
Draw it again

>>6378026
I have the opposite problem, I took a painting class years ago and can only fix things or add detail by reshaping blobs of "paint". My skills have degraded from absence and I'm playing catchup, but my eyes are still ok. I'd like some help on that, but for your problem:

Usually a person has a preference for what kind of style of painting they want, even if they aren't consciously thinking about a certain era of painting. Here are some things to keep in mind while painting:
Do you like it when it looks like you painted it, or do you want to hide it?
Are little details fun or annoying? How about highlights?
There are many ways to make a focal point, which way do you like?

And when you've figured this out, you bend more towards that direction. Since this is the master study thread, you eyeball the art movements on wikipedia or something and say, "that one". For example, someone who doesn't enjoy painstaking detail and wants a painterly look, but likes little flourishes may study impressionist artists.

I know this was posted a while ago but given how complicated the original seems to be, how did you go about starting this study? I still stumble over my own feet when doing master studies of complex work

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6400090
spend quite some time doing line art
then paint all the big shape first squint my eyes till it has similar value and color contrast (since I don't try to make it the exact color from the rei one)
when both are done the rest is just mindless zooming in and filling/rendering all the small stuff following the line while zooming out to double-check the big picture with rei one
then paint over the line and redraw some of it
notice that rei is using a different technique here with clean line art and sticking to it so the edge is cleaner and can change line art color a lot. which is hard for me to do since the ref is kinda blurry and I'm lazy so I draw loosely then paint over and redraw some of the line art

but if I do that how do I know what colors to use for shadows. Like he uses orange on the top, I don’t think just drawing would make me know how to do that.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6419617
Learn about the parts of shadows and about reflected light. Usually, if you have one surface sitting on another, the inner part of the shadow takes on some of the color and reflected light of the surface it’s sitting against - in this case, blue. As the object’s shape turns back towards the main light source, it picks up more of the surrounding environment, and you can emphasize this in a stylistic way by adding a bit more of saturated version of the main light source’s color - in this case, orange. Pic shows the parts of the shadow. The blue here is in the reflected area, and the orange is in the half tone.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6418102
Push your contrasts. Physical media and monitors both have limited blacks and whites compared to real life. That's why you have sacrifice value range in either the shadows or the lit side to give a lifelike effect. Photographs don't do that by default to not lose information. There's too much contrast between small shapes while having a lack of proper light and dark seperation of major shapes.
If you adjust the contrast a bit on both and posterize you can notice these issues more easily.

This is stylised away in a lot of anime but this shape is a combination of both the curve of the brow bone and the curve of the cheek bone. It gets easier to draw when you stop thinking of it as a protrusion and think of it more as a wedge taken out of the face to fit the eyes. If you look at a face from the side you can actually see they both meet around the outside of the eye socket. From a 3/4 view it's the recession of the eye socket that makes it look more like a ledge or bump.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6404606
Excuse the MS paint mouse drawing, this is not how to start a drawing per se, but a way to conceptualize the head. The plane of the forehead (A) hangs out like a canopy over the plane of the cheeks (C). The transition between the two planes (change in direction of the outline) is at the plane of the eye sockets (B).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6404606
Depending on the rotation of the head, the bump may be the cheek bone, the fleshy part of the cheek, or the jaw. So there is no single correct position, but a range of positions. You are interpolating between features that are themselves variable.
In short, if you try to draw this bump in the same place for every face from every angle, you will fail.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6418738
I agree with this. There’s a difference between always drawing eyes of a certain shape because you have experimented with many shapes and like that one the best, versus always drawing eyes of a certain shape because you once accidentally drew it that way and you don’t know why it looks correct but it’s the only correct-looking type of eye you can produce so you just stick with it. That’s why the bad kind of same face syndrome also usually includes same pose syndrome - the structure of that feature has not been properly understood, it’s just a good looking fluke being repeatedly copied line for line.

Notice that in >>6418721, even though they all look like the same woman, their heads are turned in different directions because he can handle drawing this faces in many poses. He understands it in 3D.

>>6398121
>>6394355
Yeah, I'm really interested in both of them. As well as Rey Bustos's Rey's Anatomy if you ever come around that.

Sadly I can't provide any thorough tips on how to scan a book but contrary to what people have said, I don't think you will destroy the binding of these books if you scanned them. Since these books are hard cover, their have a different, much more flexible and durable binding than your average paperback book.

As much as it is true that you will destroy the binding of a paperback book if you scan them it, hardcover books- those that you are not afraid to open at more then 90° degrees wont really be that damaged.

ayy thanks!
this was animated with a really simple technique. I drew out the first frame of all the debris in the air, and then just picked a random chunk and animated that single piece. when the piece finally stops moving, i just make a new layer set to hold the keyframe. then just rinse and repeat until all the individual pieces are animated. takes a long time but it makes it a bit more dynamic than just animating them all at once and accidentally making it look too uniform.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6362663
>>6362664
trace over your key drawing really really carefully. sculpt your lines with smaller strokes and use the eraser to clean it up instead of trying to wing it in one stroke. boil is usually supposed to be really subtle, so keep the onion skin on, flip between frames often, and make sure that nothing is too chaotic as it moves. think of it like you're inbetweening something that's BARELY moving at all. when you turn on the onion skin, you'd want your drawings to practically be on top of one another
boiling also tends to work best on 2s and 3s for general acting, but if you're animating a shiver/shake, then 1s usually fits a lot better.

i use tvpaint 11, only payed like £300 or so for a student licence, but i'd 100% pay full price with the time it saves, just for the out of pegs feature, onion skin settings and colour group frame flipping system alone. the timeline works flawlessly, it's easy to set up repeating, loop and hold frames, running the program is relatively light. it's easy to set up making animatics for long term projects and split them up into seperate files down the line. the colouring system is great too, speeds things up a lot, like one squiggle per frame just to fill a colour in, but i wouldn't make that part a deciding factor on getting the software.

i use flash and photoshop too for professional work, but tvpaint is what i do all of my personal stuff in, and if i get a job in TVpaint i can get it done way faster (assuming it's frame by frame drawn stuff).

if you're a student, buy it nigga. but otherwise i'm sure tvpaint 10 has most of the good features.

>>6366166
another thing that i completely forgot about that somehow i've taken for granted is that in TVpaint you can press enter to repeat your last action on the canvas. so if you fuck up drawing a line on the wrong layer, want to repeat a selection, it puts whatever you just made down again. if you select a range of frames it works across them all too with one press, so you can fill an entire animation with colour in one keyboard press. fucking revolutionary and i don't know why other art programs don't have it.

some other things, you can stretch an entire length of animation to re-time it and keep it proportionally intact. also custom brushes, you can cut out an animation and use it as a stamp / animated brush, saves a fuck load of time, and it's incorporated simply into your usual brush tool, and intuitive to use. really easy to make your own brushes that way too.

do japanese people use a different numbering system? Studying genga they use even and odd numbers which if looked at through the lens of the american numbering system would mean they animate on ones, but they don't
how do they indicate frame timings?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6373793
Do you have an example, because the Japanese timesheets look normal to me.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6373793
>Studying genga they use even and odd numbers
I just assume that's because they primarily animate on 3s and 4s?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6373793
>>6374284

they likely don't think about their 'number system', most animators don't. they just do what's required for the shot to look good, and sometimes you can get away with 4's. the usual method is to animate 24fps then just 'hold' the frames that last longer (2's, 3's, 4's) and on the rare instance you need to have a 1, you put that in. no point in trying to formulise it, use whatever frames work best wherever as long as it times out correctly. say for a movement that starts fast but you want one extra frame in there at the end to bounce back to a stopping point, it's prob gonna be even/odd or vice versa.

i've never worked on a production that wasn't default 24fps despite 95-100% of the project being animated on 2's. and usually, if you have camera moves in an environment, those need to be on 1's or things look choppy as fuck.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6373793
might depend on how they use x-sheets. sometimes they have the timing figured out beforehand or write it down as they go, but retiming later on down the pipelines might change it up and make the notes not line up well anyways.
if I'm animating with an assistant/inbetweener and need to guide them, I label keyframes just with a letter, and then use numbers counting up from 1 to label all the places that need inbetweens. it doesn't really have any relation to a x-sheet, just "INB B3-C, favor C" or some shit like that

theres no one way to storyboard but if youre starting out i suggest draw your story beats first, the most important frames that tell the story, probably the ones you have in your head (should be like 10-20 drawings depending on the length, don't draw whole scenes yet)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6383943
good rule of thumb is to know the difference between a "jumping" ball and a "bouncing" ball. a jumping ball sticks to the ground a bit longer and has way more time to squash and stretch, whereas an actual bouncing ball analogous to reality will only be on the ground for a single frame. jumping balls are typically what most non-animator animation purists would see and worship thinking it's what everybody SHOULD do, but it tends to be too over-exaggerated to be useful in many situations. a bouncing ball shouldn't contact with the ground for too long, especially if it's moving in a specific direction where the speed has to slowly roll off with every bounce.
I animated a small representation of what either looks like bouncing in place.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6384158
>12fps is the lowest the human eye perceives something as a smooth motion but I don't know if that's broscience.
Definitely bro science. If you learn to look for jitter you can notice it at up to very high framerates, and if you are immersed in a story it's hard for the framerate to screw it up so long as you establish a convention. Only when framerate changes does it force attention away from the story. Appeal > technical skill and effort. Appeal in still art is difficult, appeal in motion harder still. It has to do with how long each frame is held, but it is not just more frames is better.

>>6384158
>What's the lowest frame rate I could generally get away with without it looking like shit
if you're working at 24FPS, you could go all the way down to 4s [6FPS] for slower movements and the average viewer wouldn't even notice. for faster motions and high-paces scenes, it's probably best to go to 2s and 1s. for general character acting and dialogue, 2s, and 3s is alright in most cases, unless you're working with really wild acting and fast speaking.

>>6389102
Thank you very much anon.
In return I'll give some general advice for the thread

Heavily work on your key poses. Yeah I know it's obvious but It's very easy to just add more and more frames because it's very simple to line test with softwares. Plan the animation your head and in advance VERY carefully. "Fluidness" isn't the point in animation, the clarity of each pose and action is what matters most. you don't do a dozen unecessary movements at all times just for the sake of it (ding ding every wannabe amateur webgen animators in twitter)
Not saying it shouldn't ever be done, but you should know the rules before you bend and break them.
Don't hesitate to act the movement yourself as well. FEEL the movement.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6419142
i think the lack of spine arch is the main problem. arnie is puffing his chest out which comes from arching his mid back really hard. arnie would also have to flex his upper spine (lower neck area) forward to compensate (otherwise it would just look like he's leaning back). this all creates a big S shape in the spine.
liefeld just has his guy standing straight. captain america has the results of the S curve without the S itself. the very stiff legs and hips emphasize this lack of S.
i attached a picture of arnold in the same pose but a more similar perspective to what liefeld used. you can see that the reason why arnold's farside pec sticks out in the OP is because he's angled slightly. he isn't standing perfectly sideways like liefeld thought he was. if arnold was standing squarely sideways like captain america, you would mostly just see one pec. arnold *pretends* like he's standing sideways but he twists his spine to make his chest appear wider and bigger. arnold was very good at posing in these types of ways. liefeld was fooled by it

and then there's the fact that liefeld's guy must have a very short arm behind that shield.

posts.com:
How can I learn to render like this? This cartoonish/softer paint style. Can someone point me to a good book or video course on both rendering and color for this?

Its not only the theory honestly, its the methodology, the process. What layers are they using? What brushes? etc

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Why don't you trace the lineart and do a study like everyone else?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
see if this artist or artists like them have uploaded process videos, study that
choose any small arbitrary square inside of the image (the purple crystal on the staff would be a good start) and see if you can render something that looks just like it. experiment until you have a method that works
draw draw draw x 100000

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: hard round brush

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: There is no other way than doing a study, so try to imitate it as well as possible. Yes you will fail at first and it will look nothing like what you want, but you'll keep getting better and this also usually gives you serious gains. If I can give you some hints/advice, it seems lineart and colors are done on one layer. It's also what I'm doing and this adds a lot to the "painterly" look. You block out the shape and then paint lineart on top, lighten/darken layer modes are helpful. Don't trace the lineart like >>6418909 is suggesting because that is not the workflow here

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6418908

Basically, to clarify, you don't do clean lineart on one layer + colors underneath for this kind of artstyle so don't even try that, you won't achieve this look that way. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.sub: How do you study from books
posts.com:
I've been filted by all books about drawing I've read.
How does one approach them?
Do you copy the drawings it has? Memorize them? Read then and then try to do it? Doing it while reading it? Using it in real life?

How do you process the information in the books?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6410740
1. Make a google document with the name of the subject matter, then the book and teacher's name
2. Write down an explanation of which fundamental the book teaches, why I need to learn it and what my goals wiht it are
3. Divide the book/seminar in weeks or chapters.
4. Read 1 Chapter, write down my own understanding of it in the google document
5. Finish off by giving myself homework on it, and take a snap shot to paste it into said google document
6. Move onto the next chapter and repeat

This is the best way to actually learn on your own, you only truly understand things when you are forced to explain them to yourself in written form, then you are forced to apply it.
-
I am actually doing this exact same thing with that book you just posted. I have to do 100 figures, I got 10 down so far. I gave myself an explanation of the core ideas, from the 8 parts of the body to the rythm, story, balance, weight, CSI lines and the metholodgy applied step by step (Finding the head, then the spine, then into the pelvis using repetition lines that add flow and gesture to it, before placing wrapping lines).
posts.filename: Michael Hampton - Anatomy - Homework 1 - 100 Figure Drawings

posts.com:

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6410744
With that book specifically, its ez because Michael Hampton as a seminar that literally tells you what the homework should be

But as a rule of thumb, you are going to want to draw a shit lot of whatever they actually tried to explain in said chapter.
So, if the chapter is about learning how to use the multiplication/division technique to extend squares as they recede back into space, then you do that exercise 50 times till it becomes ez
If the chapter is about how to render a sphere, then you go and render 100 spheres from as many angles as you can imagine/find in refs

If you are looking for Michael Hamptons homework I can give it to you :o

I honestly really recommend you downliad his 10 year old seminar, mostly because you get to see him apply the method live which is pretty helpful
I believe they are available in the /video course/ general in /ic/

Here is the homework either way :o


----------------------------------------
Course Description:
As students continue to develop a basic skill set throughout this course, a special emphasis will be placed on the understanding and application of those basics to the human figure. This course will emphasize a process based approach and development of the figure heavy in an analysis of from, construction, and perspective. This course will offer and in depth study of the figure and the surface anatomy while always maintaining a grounding in the artistic and principles of design.
Week 1: Lecture: Introduction of teacher/ Goals of class. Lecture on gesture and the development of a process.

Homework: 100 Gesture Drawings (half should be done from life, the other half from Old Masters drawings, paintings or sculpture). Choose 5 of your best gestures to submit for critique and instructor feedback. Drawings may be scanned in and submitted or submitted as digital files done in photoshop or as jpgs. You may also upload one, or more, for student feedback on the class blog.
Week 2: Lecture: Connections, Shape and Understanding the skeletal landmarks.
Homework: 25 construction drawings. Drawings should follow in class process of gesture, shapes, connections, landmarks, and finally into a development of the perspectives of the torso, arms, and legs. Choose 2-5 of your best to submit for critique and instructor feedback.
Week 3: Lecture: Head Drawing. Construction and design of the human head.
Homework: 25 Head constructions. Following the in class work flow, develop the head from simple shapes into the architectural planes. Development of the features is optional. Choose 2-5 of your best to submit for critique and instructor feedback
----

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6410753
Week 4: Lecture: Muscles: Torso/trunk. Placing the anatomical shapes of the upper and lower torso based off the understanding of the skeletal landmarks.
Homework: 25 Construction drawing with the anatomy of the upper and lower torso included on top. Only develop the muscles covered within the lecture, but be sure to draw the entire pose. Choose 2-5 of your best to submit for critique and instructor feedback.
Week 5: Lecture: Torso 2.
Homework: 25 Construction drawing with the anatomy of the upper and lower torso included on top. Include the muscles discussed in the prior week as well as the anatomy of the torso. Choose 2-5 of your best to submit for critique and instructor feedback.
Week 6: Lecture: Structure and anatomy of the legs
Homework: 25 Leg and pelvis constructions. Include the anatomy on top of the underlying skeletal and perspective breakdowns. Pay close attention to the shape, gesture, and perspective of each shape as you build. Choose 2-5 of your best to submit for critique and instructor feedback.
Week 7: Lecture: The structure, design and anatomy of the upper arm and shoulders.
Homework: 25 Shoulder and arms constructions. Develop the anatomy of the upper arms together with the anatomy of the upper torso. This week should specifically focus on the shoulder girdle and the muscles of the scapula and front of the humerus. Choose 2-5 of your best to submit for critique and instructor feedback.
Week 8: Lecture: The structure, construction, and design of the forearm.
Homework: 25 Shoulder and arms constructions. Develop the anatomy of the upper arms together with the anatomy of the forearms. Choose 2 of your best to submit for critique and instructor feedback.
---------------------

Thats all of it, save it into a notepad or something :o

>>6411492
Depends on where you’re at, skill-wise and what your goals are. But in order from when I started to now, some books I’ve found helpful are:
Vilppu drawing manual, along with the video lectures
Simultaneously, The first 10-20 pages of any book on perspective to give you a rough idea of 1,2 ,3 point perspective to aid you in the goal of drawing boxes using intuition.
Hampton
Anatomy for sculptors
That Tom fox anatomy book is pretty cool.
And lots of copying art from your favourite artists. And lots of figure drawing.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6416075
this >>6416120
I have the exact same problem, anon.
Maybe it's lazyness, maybe it's ADHD, maybe it's because you have way too high expectations for yourself and you're too scared of not fullfilling them and failing.
What helped me was creating structure. But not too much structure to the point it suffocates you with no wiggle room.
I use a calendar app and make appointments for the next day before I go to sleep.
I create like 4 appointments spread throughout the day that are 60 minutes long drawing sessions.
I've noticed that if I don't do this, it's much harder for me to start drawing.
You need to give yourself restrictions if you want to get shit done.
Too much freedom will unironically limit you more.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6412909
Just extend lines from background elements that can be used for comparison with your character. In your example, you might want to draw beyond the borders of the picture because your character is in the foreground. You could extend the perspective lines of the door to where the character is standing and then project some horizontals to show you the height of the door at that location (since the character has to be a little shorter than the doorway).
>That's not intuitive!
It is if you know perspective. You don't even have to use a ruler. Just know the rules and rough it in.

for any habits you are trying to form as daily routines don't do more in a day than you can recover from by tomorrow. you wouldn't overextend andac yourself out every day at the gym because you most likely wouldn't go into the next day with enough motivation to hit the gym again. when you get burnt out set aside one day to deliberately do absolutely nothing for an entire day and hopefully by the next day you will be so sick of doing nothing that you have to do some art. it's all about forming habits. if you do something every day for 60 days on the 61st day it will feel unnatural to not do it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6415296
I do the same, it's basically like roleplay which sounds kind of autistic or cringe. I have to try and larp as my characters whenever I try to write dialogue between them. I like to put two characters in a conversation and usually have them talk about whatever. I think putting characters together and having them discuss their ideas on whatever topics can help flesh them out as individuals rather than just character tropes. I usually like to put characters with opposing beliefs against each other. I think something helpful is also having someone to bounce ideas off of. I used to "roleplay" with other people, but it's not like the typical weird ERP roleplaying. It was more similar to writing an actual story where you choose a setting and each person takes turn writing full paragraphs and improv. There was a much stronger focus on writing an actual story and dialogue. You could consider it as writing a story with a partner rather than roleplaying. It's sounds cringe but it did help me empathize more with my characters and try to understand them. It also helped me understand how other people characterize and write their own characters. I don't know if this will help anyone since I'm still awful at writing, but I did know a lot of great writers who would write with me.

You'd think, right? But even if you don't notice it you have a range of emotions you can feel. What happens when the emotion you want to draw goes beyond what you can imagine?

Sounds like bullshit but try it once and see it works.

>Post your sculpt.
Pic rel. fresh out of mold, before cleaning.

To anons who want start with sculpting. There is no "clay" for everything and you need difrent clay for difrent projects - it's matter of advantages and disadvantages.
First "clay" to buy I recomend normal waterbase clay (you can dig it yourself) or cheap plasticine, mix it up for one colour (that one is more easier for start). Next one, you can buy some "plastelina bezsiarkowa" in "skin tone colour" or a bit softer "plastelina techniczna" (also sulfurfree) in grey colour. Don't buy expensive stuff in begining it's not worth it.
Tools: 90% of work you should do with your hands. For starter, size appropriate metal scapula, butterknife, few sticks with difrent carved points, wire for armature and pliers for bending and cuting, scrap wood boad for base. Later you can estimate what kind of tools you need base on scale of work.
Skills: anathomy, obsevation are key at beginning and good ref. pic.

Hey there Anon, I recently started getting into clay - I have a lot of plans and I am a complete scrub, however here are some pointers as I have been doing some recent investigations
The clay you are looking for is Polymer Clay, it is easy to form and you can cook it in an oven - it is not food safe, as it is made up of plastics. (although any on-brand types of clay should be safe from toxins, there used to be a toxic plastic mixed in but most brands has removed this.)
When buying clay there is a typical difference between more expensive and cheaper brands, FIMO is a good lower cost brand, which does have some flexibility in the finished items.
I personally am planning to bulk buy cosclay, cosclay is even more flexible than Fimo.
When buying polymer clay you may notice there is a soft, medium and harder type - harder is more difficult to form, however it keeps details and frankly the soft clay will just fall apart if you are trying to make a standing clay sculpture.
For painting the sculpture I recommend using acryllic paint, fitting as that too is artificial plastics
Good luck with the arts anon

Use google and google translate, look for the light brown colour. No YT reviews, it's good.
>Excepts children's clay who is simply shit for everything.
If one brand is shit, just check another. It's cheap so you can experiment and find/mix to make good one.
>What can you tell us.
Fuck, it's very broad subcject. You will use eg. beeswax for metal casting, not the ceramic clay. You could but it generate more steps you need to make metal cast. For beginig and training, clay and plasticine is more than enough.
>How did you make this one ?
1. sculpt with plasticine, pic rel.
2. put walls to seperate 2 parts of mold (line was from side of neck, behind the ear to the top of head and mirrored down)
3. mix plaster/gipsum and make to part mold (remember to isolete first part)
4. open mold, remove plastecine, isolate inside of mold with ladr
5. mix plaster/gipsum and fill the insiede, give it about 30 min after it's hard and very carfully with knife/waste chisel carve out mold
>How the fuck can you work monster clay exactly ?
Dunno, for me it looks similar to beeswax with few addons, so propably you need more heat than your hands or you need stroner hands with less fat. For now, leave it or sell it. You don't know how to use it and focus on difrent stuff.

Also if you want to scan sculpture and then work it in 3D, just work from start in 3D. For now it's waste of time and energy with scaning.
Just have some fun with clay and learn human anathomy, sill of manipulating clay will come with time.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6411016
Good question, it have it's pros and cons.
Cons:
>bigger mess, and a lot of plaster dust that you don't want to inhale
>more waste of materials
>when you make a mistake it's hard to repair, in general it's harder for beginners
>akes more time than just sculpt it from clay and cast it
>if you sculpt 1:1 head that way it will be heavier than just casted in plaster
>casting in bronze need more steps that way
Pros:
>it's good exercise in carving
>it's good for casting small metal plaques
>it's easier to make geometrical figures with polished surface
>you can directly carve multi-use mold for casting pewter
>it's cheaper than marble and easier to carve than sandstone

Why You Should Copy Anime:

**Strive for quantity AND quality.**

Anime Studying:
>Copy anime references exactly and draw them from memory. Use illustrations, screenshots, anime figures, 3D models, etc.
>Don’t copy recklessly. Use construction, color theory, and other fundamental concepts to rehearse a drawing process that you can later easily manipulate for original artwork.
>Post all of your anime studies. Post even when you’re told not to. Create an art community that actually draws and improves together instead of just talking about it.
>Number your attempts and link to your previous posts.
>Critiquers should lead by example by posting their studies.

General Anime Style Discussion:
>Questions about achieving certain styles/techniques/compositions etc.
>Drawing methods, study habits, resources, tutorials, tools, software, etc
>Be specific and try to post a sample of your study attempts before asking for help.

**Draw copies from good anime styled references to mindfully up our mileage, internalize appealing aesthetics, and learn from each other’s processes and knowledge.**

I lay down flats once I got a fairly solid drawing. It helps me see my proportions better. A normal person has eight heads for their height. And your hands wide open should cover your face. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6397736
Just wanted to add, zoom out when you ink. You are sketching your inks and that's why they look chunky. Sketching is a wrist action, you want to work more from the elbow and the shoulder rather than the wrist when inking. And you want to stay zoomed out so you can make big bold lines in single motions and be able to see the width of the lines relative to each other. Big lines on the outside small lines on the inside is the basic rule of thumb. It's more nuanced than that but you get the idea.

posts.com:
Recently I decided to try to learn how to draw properly, It was something I always wanted to do but I never had the motivation to continue. I gues scute girls is all the motivation I needed. I think I got a decent balance of practical practice and fun practice, I like to study poses, form and figure drawing, shapes in perspective, maybe look up a few anatomy references to get an idea about something that seems interesting/I want to draw. And then just draw characters I like.

But I'm not sure how to approach the learning process, I'm having a lot of fun, but I'm not sure what to learn and when. Like perspective is something I never think about, I'm not sure if it's better to think about it always or just leave it as a second thought for now. I want to learn shadow and light sources too. I guess there's too much I want to learn so I'm a bit lost. I'm thinking about keeping the volume of drawings(sketches, figure drawing, imagination, etc) as high as I can just to get more general practice, information and build my mental "reference book", maybe do the drawabox excercices that help with line confidence. My endgoal is being able to do unusual/extreme angles in my drawings and understand them well, I find those kind of drawings extremely charming. Obviously anime is one of the biggest appeals and what I want to draw, but I'm also interested in realistic drawings, portraits, scenery, etc. I'm honestly enjoying myself a lot.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6404681
when you begin figure drawing or copying, there is an immense temptation to immediately start making the final outlines, like tracing a picture.
instead, first try roughly laying down the main shapes as a sketch underneath. check it for proportions, is one part too small/big? also check for angles by holding your pen at whatever angle you want to check in the original image, then move that pen over to yours to compare if it's off.

>>6408735
You got good replies already, I would also add that anime style in itself is a lot more idealized (whether girls or guys). To understand why it's as such you'd need to study Japanese society and the psychological aspect behind the evolution of such artistic style. Once you do you then understand the groups of people in the West who like it vs. those who don't like it and the differences between their respective cognitions. One key reason is how much the average American/Westerner cares about how they are seen by others and whether they abide to what's "objective" or not, and thus how much they themselves get subconsciously shaped by others in the process.

That's one perspective. Others exist and continue to come through.
For example it's been a few years now that Western women artists (and those who identify with them) have been vehemently against anime because it often represents youth and beauty at a level which makes them personally feel uncomfortable at a less conscious level. This is a not a popular or nice thing to say (the truth never is really), but women's value are still very rooted in their appearance. As women get into their mid-20s and approach their 30s they watch their value decay and they come to understand that they simply cannot match the intuitive idealized expectation of most men anymore from a beauty standpoint (which anime showcases well on a certain level). The opposite isn't true: I don't think there are many guys feeling envious of anime guys. They appear cool and that's it, or if anything they can inspire growth.
This is why we're now witnessing an epidemy on social medias (and even this board now) with them calling any artist who dares to like anime "pedos" and whatnot, as a way to try and shape the norms, to shape reality, in a way that is more comfortable to them and can bring power back to them in this gender dynamic seen from a larger scale.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6419032
You're meant to stylize cheeks, chins, etc, when drawing anime (it applies to Western styles stuff too). In other words you can't 100% rely on 3D understanding.
To be fair this applies to realism too. Even the tradionalists will interpret and stylize things as reality cannot always be properly displayed on a flat surface.
So basically the construction method will differ based on the style you're aiming for. Anime is a big medium. """Loomis""" might work for pic related but might not a good choice for something more stylized or moe etc...

I still don't get the narrative that trad and digital art are on different ends of the spectrum. I mostly do cartooning and work digitally, but I've sketched plenty in pencil, and drawn in charcoal and pastels, and never really saw a difference in my skill between the mediums. In fact, my pencil sketches drawn from live models during lifedrawing sessions are some of my best observational drawings. Before I moved to digital drawing, I'd draw on paper and scan the results.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6418251
I think it only really matters toward the end of the spectrum and for painting.
Digital even if using basic tools is still a results oriented medium. It doesn’t matter if you use the brush or pen tool the result is the same, pixels will be changed and look how you want.

Traditional painting is heavily medium focused the entire process is dictated by your tools and it will completely change the result and how you go about accomplishing something. If you fuck up the early steps you either incorporate or scrap the whole thing.

So the mindset in going into a painting is just very different between the 2. At the entry levels it’s the same though because a pencil is a pencil.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6416749
(Clockwise order)
So-bin
Murata
Atmosphere sketchbooks has sketches from I think 3 artists
Settei Dreams has artbooks and storyboards of anime
Horikoshi has sketches
And Inoue Kiyoshirou has an "artbook" which is just the sketches of a hentai he drew.

In the end, you won't find many "artbooks" like the yoshinari one especially of artists' sketches. Mostly finished work which you said you're not looking for.
Also, don't limit to just artbooks, copy directly from manga too.(Which is how most mangakas got good.) since they're basically just clean sketches

Lastly, don't hoard books, I recommend copying front to back 1 at a time before moving onto the next one every single week.
Hope I helped ;)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6416988
Depending on how strong your fundamentals are, it will extend your understanding of them. If you don't know perspective then you can't understand how the artist is playing with perspective. Master studies are typically done to see how a specific artist solved a problem. There is a big difference between how a sculptor solves painting clothing folds and a comic artist and a painter and one or all of them may be compatible with the style you inevitably end up with but you won't know unless you do the studies to begin with.

>>6416368
Soul is capturing things you like and your ability to convey not just the thing but your liking of it. Even if the execution is flawed, the artist's feeling for the subject will show if he has soul. The reason why all these technical-emphasis examples of artists are said to lack soul is because the subject is boring or uninspiring even if a skilled likeness is produced. I remember being at an art museum once in Philly and they had a series of American paintings of frontier scenes, one of which was of a hunter and his dog and from it you could tell how much the artist appreciated the animal. The rest of the painting was well executed in terms of composition and detail but the dog especially seemed to come to life as the center of the artist's vision, just as the dog would have been vital to the frontiersman

Proko's issue is that he's an atelierfag that basically only ever drew from life and never drew from imagination. He also didn't study his references to memorize their structures for reproduction from memory, only enough to recognize the figure's landmarks so that he could copy more easily.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6415532
That article is referring to sight size and I agree it will cripple you in the long run. What you are talking about though is just measuring / comparative measuring, which is just very useful and makes it easier to double check yourself and be more precise. Make sure to have your arm fully stretched while doing it, Proko has a decent vid on it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Holding out your pencil/drawing tool and your thumb to check proportions and compare angles on your subject with the angles you're drawing at various times while you work is not the same as working entirely in the sight-size method, which from a quick glance seems to be what the article is criticizing

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Another anon mentioned it but sighting is holding the pencil and measuring proportions. Sight sizing is what the article is talking about and it involves lightning up the model and the canvas in perspective.

Sighting is good to do especially for checking proportions and does not limit your ability to scale and size. Sightsizing that the article talks about limits this ability which is why it’s not recommended.

Yeah, except Ai art is not expression in the slightest. You write it a prompt that has like 1 sentence of actual information about the picture and then either full paragraph of buzzwords to remove artefacts if you are using Stable Diffusion, or no buzzwords at all since you are using superior Midjurney. Your entire expression if just the one sentence that is written in the most plain way possible, so that CLIP can understand what you are saying, and then choosing which artstyle you want it made in. The lack of control makes it almost impossible to use as medium for expression. However using AI imagery to photobash a painting is form of expression, since it is influenced by your character.

This is why everyone says AI art looks all the same, not because AI can only do one artstyle, but because no matter who prompted it, it all ends up being the same group of artstyles, because the prompter is not relevant to the picture, it is the dataset you trained. This is why prompters will never be artists and will always be glorified commissioners. 2 people using Midjurney makes no difference, but one person using Stable Diffusion and Midjurney makes all the difference between the two, since the artist here is the machine.

Of course, people who use the first iterations of a cheap AI work and throw it out there without much thought and for quick cash do seem lame, but people who don't question the work and its quality and just use it for themselves without much thought either seem just as lame to me.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6345321
I think it's a matter of inspiration and habits. I'm a big fan of Deathburger, Geof Darrow and Moebius. I replicated a lot of things by studying these, including saturating the canvas with detail. I guess it became an automatism after doing it for years. WHAT to (specifically) draw in areas is often context dependant, but also composition dependant. There are time where you don't want to fill certain area to create some sort of rythm in the visuals.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6345141
>I really like that interpretation!
Thank you. I had a completely different idea and then this popped into my head and I ran with it. After checking a few other forums and what was posted there, I'm glad I changed it because my original idea wasn't that original.
>>6345271
>id be proud of these ones
I like how they turned out. Especially coming off of Scrape (the angle caused me heartburn with the anatomy and I think I should have inked it with a brush but didn't have it handy)
>>6345321
This is >>6344835. I think part of it is influences (I'm also fan of Geof Darrow and Moebius and also Arthur Adams). Part of it is understanding my limitations (I don't like how my crosshatching turns out so I prefer to use details to communicate values rather than hatching). Final part is readability, but this is more of a gut thing for me. Sometimes I just feel a part of the piece is missing something (in my "bluff" pic, the troll looked too blank without the skin blemishes). Hope this helps.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6346855
>I will consciously try to make over-detailed drawings for a while, as an experiment
Go for it! I think this is a great time to take risks. Couple things to keep in mind as you experiment. Details draw the eye, so if you aren't careful they could distract from the main subject of the piece (but they can also guide the eye to the subject). Work in stages, each stage adding more details. Also, details are a good way (esp. in ink) to turn mistakes into "happy accidents"

>>6346855
im sorry i misunderstood. to give an idea how i personally go about it, my fairy one would be good to talk about since that was put together mostly piecemeal:
>pencil in fairy giving candy. lollipops are typical candy imagery, so go with that
>want my three characters to be expressive. young boy is kind of pushy, so hes up front. tall boy is older, so more apprehensive
> want to fill in the foreground, so decided to do children also eating candy. gives the idea of a "living" world. also kids are fun to draw
> think it would be funny to have the tooth fairy in cahoots with the dentist, so decide to insinuate a dentist building in the background. also funny to me to have an ominous dentist shadow just standing there menacingly
> make loopy letters to go along with lollipop swirls. add lights to five it a "carnival" vibe
> start inking foreground and midground. i want the fairy character to be slightly ominous, but not "evil" so keep hatch shading to a reasonable amount
> chose to go with bricks for the building, as its common facade work for buildings like that. think of adding ivy for foliage and interest, but decide against it as it would look too cluttered
> brick inking is a typical style ive done before, just using a tried and true, low-effort brick shading
> decide to add a little screaming boy in the far right window to fill it in and it makes me smile
so, as dumb as it sounds, im kind of making up a "story" as i go, and that helps me piece it together. another popular artist who does this is bob ross, just watch some of his vids and he makes up a "story" for it as he goes. also, weirdly enough, meatcanyon is also good to watch as he has a similar wandering train of thought as he does his sketches.

>>6349056
Day 28. Leaned a new thing. If you use the liquid latex type resists when doing alcohol ink washes after inking do not put the ink washes down heavily. It can cause the resist itself to seep into the top layer of your paper (I was using Bristol rather than watercolor paper). If this happens when you try to remove the resist it will remove the top layer of paper and take any line work with it. That's what happened to the moon in the upper left. It seems to be fine if you just do light alcohol washes and let them dry between though. Watercolor paper may be a little more resilient.

posts.com:
>>6354175
Wash looks good. I too struggle with streaky washes when using alcohol, but you can mitigate that by using a little water or just doing water + ink washes. The streakyness is because the alcohol is evaporating really fast. It's a double edged sword. On one hand it keeps the paper from buckling, on the other if you're not fast enough you'll get streaks in large areas. It's great for building up localized shadow quickly without over wetting the paper though.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6411119
Animation memes are interesting because the majority of videos aren't any deeper than 'here's my oc's backstory'. AMs are designed to be repetitive and look alike. You can draw with different artstyles, and use different colors and music, but the vast majority are just headbops. Children like them because they are repetitive.
Because AMs became so popular, in ~2017, the community collapsed under the weight of copycats and art drama. I haven't looked at the community on Youtube for a while, so I don't know how popular the videos are. On Scratch, a kid-focused website (I've used it since I was a kid and I still like it), children and teens still make them. It's easy for a child to draw/animate a headbop instead of, for example, a dance.
Even though animation memes aren't deep, young people still like them. Unless you have complicated backgrounds or movements, AMs are easy to make. They're a stepping stone to more complex animation, and that's all they should be treated as.

Fully automated AI image generators are really stupid, not needed and make way too much decisions for the user, but they are right about how it works.

AI learns from adding noise and then denoising again. After that it’s able to use those patterns in a Gaussian noise and generate actual new data.

AI can be used to plagiarize and it can be really good at that, but you need to actively force that by fine tuning, img2img or prompting in certain ways that force a match.

While it is true that the human brain can be thought of as a biological computer, there are some important differences between the two. For one, computers are typically designed to perform specific tasks, whereas the human brain is capable of a much wider range of functions, including sensory perception, movement, and abstract thought. Additionally, computers are built using artificial materials, whereas the human brain is made up of complex networks of neurons and other cells.

Another key difference is the way that computers and the human brain process information. Computers use a binary system of zeros and ones to store and manipulate data, whereas the human brain uses complex networks of neurons to encode and process information. This means that the human brain is capable of parallel processing, where multiple tasks can be carried out simultaneously, whereas most computers are limited to sequential processing, where tasks are carried out one at a time.

Overall, while there are some similarities between the human brain and a computer, there are also many important differences that make the two very different in terms of their capabilities and the way they process information.

>>6402929
>>6403314
NTA but
>detail
>finished/more effort
That's not what the difference between the two is, or at least not the true difference. You're only seeing the surface level. The real differences here are

1.) A far better understanding of form. The face on the right is the most striking example, the way that the eyes are drawn indicates the head as a rounded volume with mass, whereas the left is a flat shape with sticker eyes applied to it. The jacket, clothes and even hair made of distinct, solid masses overlaid upon and wrapping around the body in layers. They all feel like they have weight and force applied to them as well. If you were really paying attention, you'll also notice very subtle indicators implying forms like the bones and tendons of the hand and the wrist under the skin- like the clothes, there is a feeling of the skin stretched upon and wrapping around these delicate forms.

2.) Better understanding of subject matter. Not only does the artist have a better understanding of human anatomy, they have an understanding of the anatomy of EVERYTHING in the piece. The jacket, the shirt, the pants, the hair, the skin and bone, they know the parts, the materials, how they fit together, and most importantly WHY that they are the way they are and act the way they do. This is why the clothes, the hair, the skin have such definite mass and purposeful application of forces upon them. See those crisp, chunky folds in the jacket on the right and compare them to the almost vacuum sealed, skintight jacket on the left with muddy indefinite marks indicating the idea of wrinkles that the artist knows should be there but doesn't understand how they work as 3D form, or the properties of the material that they're deforming.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6400360

I'll try to list what the details are hopefully so me and others can know what to look for.

The pose is the same between them, lets say the reference picture was just like the pose on the left.

Drawing exactly what you see in the reference is good practice, but you can take the time to "improve" every step of the process, and go beyond the reference. I think that's what he did here, because ist not like you will find a picture you can copy 100% and leave it as it is.

>Jacket
The old jacket is quite normal, the wrinkles are all over the place which might be realistic but you can add character into everything you draw, including wrinkles. The right pic changes the type of coat completely, its now more of a rain coat made of a heavier material. The sleeves are way wider, and it looks too big for her, that creates appeal.

>jeans
The left pic has very basic wrinkles added as a halfasssed attempt, just being more careful with sticking to proper anatomy makes a huge difference in tight clothes. The pic on the right has her legs closer to the correct length, and it wrinkles only where it bends. Which is mostly better to do.The waist of her jeans also dip down as it can in real life, instead of being perfectly horizontal as I would have drawn it. It has a 3d form as it goes aroudn her waist, and you can see it with the belt loops, so it goes in a circle AND it dips down, creating a whole lot of depth. In the left pic, its all obscured by the long sweater which is not drawn to be round at all if you look at the hem.

>body
the head is tilted on two axis, down and away, she's not facing the camera, which adds appeal. Her hair slumps down and travels along her body like water, adding more depth. Left girl has everything drawn separately as if it was pasted on, right girl has every element interacting with each other with gravity.

running out of characters but the sweater crop adding shadow is another depth thing

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6408616
That's true. However, the right eye's (our left) perspective is a little off. It doesn't match the shape of the other eye, or conform to the eye socket and surface of the face correctly.
Errors aside, even at a more frontal angle the eyes can still be pushed to feel more three dimensional. If you look at her other artworks where she's drawing normally, you'll notice that she always pushes the eyes as close to the side of the face as she can to create a feeling of them curving around the form of the head, even in straight frontal shots. It's not something exclusive to her either, if you pay attention, you'll actually see this technique being used in a lot of anime and anime-style artwork. It's a more subdued form of forced perspective that, while not technically correct, sells a heightened feeling of depth to the viewer.
Incidentally, this is why 3D modeling and animating in the anime style is so difficult.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6409467
It's not fucked, the cartoony proportions are great, so yeah I think a non-artist would think it's just fine, but there are lots of easy ways to improve it. I'm a beginner though, so take my comments with a grain of salt since this is just advice based on techniques I've read up on.

The main thing to fix it would just be to clean up your lines. Like on the feet you have some double wide lines right on the end of them and it just looks messy so get rid of those. You have that too at the bottom of your character's head which could be seen as shadowing, but unless you emphasize it a bit more to me it just looks like a blob of messy linework.

In addition you have lots of doubling going on with your linework in general and while it can be a stylistic choice, typically it looks better to get rid of them. The pic here shows what I'm talking about and no I don't know what it says, it was just the best image I could find to display it.

You also want to generally avoid outlines from different elements of a character intersecting. Like the outlines of the dude's eyes and hair meet and it looks messy so try and keep the lines one pixel in width so the lines are clean or provide a gap between the two elements so each part is distinct.

Other than some simple line cleanup your little dude looks good! I always have trouble getting eyes to look good with pixels and those look nice. It would not take much to make him look better!
